p.s: The author makes use of communicative strategies as well as stylistic devices which will be analyzed in the following, to convince the reader of his view.
Worne uses predominantly formal language, with the exception of a few words, like Cobblers (l. 15) for example.
They also make frequent use of inclusive language to address the reader directly, especially when appealing for change with the parents of the UK which they are part of (cf. l. 32 and I'm one).

By using a number of studies and figures like the latest national school exam results (l. 7) or a recent CBI/Pearson Education and Skills Survey (l. 19), Worne lends more credibility to his argument that there is decreasing amount of language-learning students.

the text shows a frequent prevalence of hyphens, for example in l. 26 ( Number of students are opting to do so - more should) or in l. 4 ([...] at university level has been in steady decline - and sadly [...]).
By that, the author grants the readers attention and puts emphasizing on the point they are making.

By enumerating the aunt languages are essential for our trade, prosperity, cultural exports, diplomacy and national security (l. 17) they also stress the importance of their appeal to increase the number of UK students choosing to study for and languages again.
Worne dedicates a whole paragraph to state opposing argument representing them in an ironic way (cf. l. 12-15).
They also contradict the opposing argument immediately after stating them.

For example, by saying that everyone speaks English in the world of business (l. 12f.) and then again saying that they are not right afterwards (cf. l. 13), the reader gets the impression that the opposing argument or nonsense or at least not very striking.
Worne only uses a few metaphors, like home-grown talent (l. 22) or essential strings to our children's hours (l. 34) to make the article more visual to the reader.
Their sparing use of metaphors generally makes the article seem more factual.

In conclusion, Worne's use of language and communicative strategies helps to support his argumentation and appeal that more students should study for languages, especially with regard to the modern globalized world in which language skills are essential for trade, communication, security and jobs.

His use of inclusive language call mom as well as the metaphors address the reader which are predominantly expect us to be parents of the UK directly to stress their role as part of these needed developments.
